nexttext:
We say that $G$ is a {\it $c$-expander with respect to $w$} $(c>0)$,
if $\Phi_w(S)\ge c$ for every subset $S\subseteq V$ with
$0<w(S)<w(V)$.

To generalize this notion to multiway cuts, it is perhaps easier to
formulate the contrapositive. We say that $(G,w)$ is {\it
$(k,c)$-partitionable}, if $V$ has a partition $V=S_1\cup\dots\cup
S_k$ into sets with $w(S_i)>0$ such that
prevtext:
\maketitle

In the theory of Riemann manifolds, two basic theorems connect the
geometry of the manifold to the spectrum of the Laplace operator on
the manifold: Courant's Nodal Theorem and Cheeger's Inequality. Both
of these have analogues in graph theory. Analogues of Cheeger's
Inequality for graphs have been proved by Alon and Milman
\cite{AlMi}, Alon \cite{Al}, Dodziuk and Kendall \cite{DoKe}, Jerrum
and Sinclair \cite{JeSi} and others. Analogues of the Nodal Theorem
have been proved by van der Holst \cite{HvH} and van der Holst,
Lov\'asz and Schrijver \cite{HLS}, and generalized by Colin de
Verdi\`ere \cite{CdVbook}. In this note we prove a result that can be
thought of as a common generalization of the Nodal Theorem and (one
direction of) Cheeger's Inequality for graphs.

To motivate our work, let us cite (informally) some results on the
spectrum of the Laplacian of a graph. It is a basic simple fact that
the graph is connected if and only if the smallest eigenvalue (which
is always $0$) has multiplicity one. The theorem of Alon and Milman
gives a quantitative version of this: If the second smallest
eigenvalue is at least ${\varepsilon}>0$, then the graph is an expander, where
the expansion rate depends on ${\varepsilon}$. The Lemma of van der Holst
implies that if $x$ is an eigenvector of the Laplacian of a connected
graph $G$ belonging to the second smallest eigenvalue, and this
eigenvalue has multiplicity one, then the positive and negative
supports of $x$ induce connected subgraphs. A consequence of our
results is that if the second and third eigenvalues of the Laplacian
are at least ${\varepsilon}$ apart, then the subgraphs induced by the positive
and negative supports of $x$ are expanders (in a weighted sense).

Let $(w_i:~i\in V)$ be a weighting of the nodes of the graph
$G=(V,E)$ with nonnegative weights. For $S\subseteq V$ with
$0<w(S)<w(V)$, define
text:
\[
w(S) = \sum_{i\in S} w_i \quad\text{and}\quad
\Phi_w(S) = \Phi_{G,w}(S) = \frac{\sum_{i\in S,j\in V\setminus S}
\sqrt{w_iw_j}}{\min \bigl(w(S), w(V\setminus S)\bigr)}.
\]

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="w(S)=\sum_{i\in S}w_{i}\quad\text{and}\quad\Phi_{w}(S)=\Phi_{G,w}(S)=\frac{%
\sum_{i\in S,j\in V\setminus S}\sqrt{w_{i}w_{j}}}{\min\bigl{(}w(S),w(V%
\setminus S)\bigr{)}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>w</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>S</mi></mrow></munder><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </mo><mtext>and</mtext></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mi>w</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mi>G</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>w</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>S</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>∖</mo><mi>S</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></msub><msqrt><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></mrow></msqrt></mrow><mrow><mi>min</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">(</mo><mrow><mi>w</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>w</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>∖</mo><mi>S</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

for all $1\le i\le k$. If $k>2$, then merging two classes in such a
partition the new class still satisfies \eqref{EQ:1}, and hence every
$(k,c)$-partitionable weighted graph is $(k-1,c)$-partitionable as
well.

For a vector $x\in{\mathbb R}^V$, we denote by ${\text{\rm supp}}_+(x)=\{i\in V:~x_i>0\}$
and ${\text{\rm supp}}_-(x)=\{i\in V:~x_i>0\}$ its positive and negative support,
and let $G_x^+$ and $G_x^-$ denote the subgraphs of $G$ induced by
${\text{\rm supp}}_+(x)$ and ${\text{\rm supp}}_-(x)$ respectively.

\begin{theorem}\label{THM:1}
Let $G=(V,E)$ be a graph and let $\lambda_1=0\le\lambda_2\le
\lambda_3\le \dots\le\lambda_n$ be the eigenvalues of its Laplacian
$L$. Let $y$ be an eigenvector belonging to $\lambda_k$ $(1\le k\le
n)$, and let $w_i=y_i^2$ and $c=(\lambda_{k+1}-\lambda_k)/2$. Suppose
that the weighted graph $(G_y^+, w)$ is $(a,c)$-partitionable, and
$(G_y^-, w)$ is $(b,c)$-partitionable. Then $a+b\le k$.
\end{theorem}

For $k=2$, we get the corollary:

\begin{corollary}\label{COR:1}
If $y$ is an eigenvector belonging to $\lambda_2$, then both $G_y^+$
and $G_y^-$ are $(\lambda_3-\lambda_2)/2$-expanders with respect to
the weights $y_i^2$.
\end{corollary}

\begin{proof}
Let us write $G^+=G^+_y$, $V^+={\text{\rm supp}}_+(y)$ and
$\Phi^+(S)=\Phi_{G_y^+,w}(S)$ for $S\subseteq V^+$, and define $G^-$,
$V^-$ and $\Phi^-$ analogously. Let $V^+=V_1\cup\dots\cup V_a$ be a
partition with $\Phi^+(V_i) < c$, and let $V^-=V_{a+1}\cup\dots\cup
V_{a+b}$ be an analogous partition. Let us assume (by way of
contradiction) that $a+b\ge k+1$; we may assume (by merging partition
classes) that $a+b=k+1$.

Let $M=L-\lambda_kI$, so that $My=0$. Let $y^i\in {\mathbb R}^V$ denote the
vector obtained from $y$ by replacing all entries in $V\setminus V_i$
by $0$. So $y^i\ge0$ for $1\le i\le a$, $y^i\le0$ for $a+1\le i\le
a+b$, and $y=y^1+\dots+y^{k+1}$. Let $z_i=\|y^i\|$,
${\widehat}{y}^i=(1/z_i)y^i$, and $z=(z_1,\dots,z_{k+1}){^\top}$. Consider the
$(k+1)\times(k+1)$ matrix $B$ defined by

For a vector $x\in{\mathbb R}^V$, we denote by ${\text{\rm supp}}_+(x)=\{i\in V:~x_i>0\}$
and ${\text{\rm supp}}_-(x)=\{i\in V:~x_i>0\}$ its positive and negative support,
and let $G_x^+$ and $G_x^-$ denote the subgraphs of $G$ induced by
${\text{\rm supp}}_+(x)$ and ${\text{\rm supp}}_-(x)$ respectively.

\begin{theorem}\label{THM:1}
Let $G=(V,E)$ be a graph and let $\lambda_1=0\le\lambda_2\le
\lambda_3\le \dots\le\lambda_n$ be the eigenvalues of its Laplacian
$L$. Let $y$ be an eigenvector belonging to $\lambda_k$ $(1\le k\le
n)$, and let $w_i=y_i^2$ and $c=(\lambda_{k+1}-\lambda_k)/2$. Suppose
that the weighted graph $(G_y^+, w)$ is $(a,c)$-partitionable, and
$(G_y^-, w)$ is $(b,c)$-partitionable. Then $a+b\le k$.
\end{theorem}

For $k=2$, we get the corollary:

\begin{corollary}\label{COR:1}
If $y$ is an eigenvector belonging to $\lambda_2$, then both $G_y^+$
and $G_y^-$ are $(\lambda_3-\lambda_2)/2$-expanders with respect to
the weights $y_i^2$.
\end{corollary}

\begin{proof}
Let us write $G^+=G^+_y$, $V^+={\text{\rm supp}}_+(y)$ and
$\Phi^+(S)=\Phi_{G_y^+,w}(S)$ for $S\subseteq V^+$, and define $G^-$,
$V^-$ and $\Phi^-$ analogously. Let $V^+=V_1\cup\dots\cup V_a$ be a
partition with $\Phi^+(V_i) < c$, and let $V^-=V_{a+1}\cup\dots\cup
V_{a+b}$ be an analogous partition. Let us assume (by way of
contradiction) that $a+b\ge k+1$; we may assume (by merging partition
classes) that $a+b=k+1$.

Let $M=L-\lambda_kI$, so that $My=0$. Let $y^i\in {\mathbb R}^V$ denote the
vector obtained from $y$ by replacing all entries in $V\setminus V_i$
by $0$. So $y^i\ge0$ for $1\le i\le a$, $y^i\le0$ for $a+1\le i\le
a+b$, and $y=y^1+\dots+y^{k+1}$. Let $z_i=\|y^i\|$,
${\widehat}{y}^i=(1/z_i)y^i$, and $z=(z_1,\dots,z_{k+1}){^\top}$. Consider the
$(k+1)\times(k+1)$ matrix $B$ defined by

$M$ in an appropriate orthonormal basis. By the Interlacing

prevtext: Let $C$ be a symmetric $(k+1)\times(k+1)$ matrix, given by
text:
\[
C_{ij}=
  \begin{cases}
   B_{ij}  & \text{if $i\not=j$ and either $i,j\le a$ or $i,j\ge a+1$}, \\
   \displaystyle -\sum_{r\le a, r\not=i} \frac{z_r}{z_i}B_{ir} & \text{if $i=j\le a$}, \\
   \displaystyle -\sum_{r>a,r\not=j}^{a+b} \frac{z_r}{z_i} B_{ir} & \text{if $i=j\ge a+1$}, \\
   0,  & \text{otherwise}.
  \end{cases}
\]

nexttext:
This matrix is positive semidefinite. Indeed, we have
$(C-B)z=Cz-Bz=0$. Let $D={\text{\rm diag}}(z)$, then the matrix
$D^{-1}(C-B)D^{-1}$ has nonnegative entries in the diagonal,
nonpositive entries everywhere else, and every row-sum is $0$. So
this matrix is diagonally dominant, and hence positive semidefinite,
which implies that $C-B$ is positive semidefinite. It follows that
$\mu_{k+1}$, the largest eigenvalue of $B$, is bounded above by the
largest eigenvalue $\lambda_{\max}(C)$ of the matrix $C$. Hence by
\eqref{EQ:X},
prevtext:
if $i\le a$, and we get the same bound in the case when $i>a$.

It is easy to check that the matrix $C-B$ is given by
text:
\[
(C-B)_{ij}=  \begin{cases}
   - B_{ij}  & \text{if $i\le a<j$ or $j\le a<i$}, \\
   \sum_{r=1}^a \frac{z_r}{z_i}B_{ir} & \text{if $i=j\ge a+1$}, \\
   \sum_{r=a+1}^{a+b} \frac{z_r}{z_i} B_{ir} & \text{if $i=j\le a$}, \\
   0,  & \text{otherwise}.
  \end{cases}
\]

displaystyle="false"><mfrac><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>r</mi></msub><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>B</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>r</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mtext>if </mtext><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>j</mi><mo>≥</mo><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd displaystyle="false"><mfrac><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>r</mi></msub><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>B</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>r</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mtext>if </mtext><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>j</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mtext>otherwise</mtext><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext:
This matrix is positive semidefinite. Indeed, we have
$(C-B)z=Cz-Bz=0$. Let $D={\text{\rm diag}}(z)$, then the matrix
$D^{-1}(C-B)D^{-1}$ has nonnegative entries in the diagonal,
nonpositive entries everywhere else, and every row-sum is $0$. So
this matrix is diagonally dominant, and hence positive semidefinite,
which implies that $C-B$ is positive semidefinite. It follows that
$\mu_{k+1}$, the largest eigenvalue of $B$, is bounded above by the
largest eigenvalue $\lambda_{\max}(C)$ of the matrix $C$. Hence by
\eqref{EQ:X},

nexttext:
Indeed, let $u$ be the eigenvector of $C$ belonging to
$\lambda_{\max}(C)$. We may assume that $u_1=z_1>0$ and $|u_i|\le
z_i$ for all $i$. Then, using \eqref{EQ:DIAG1},

$\lambda_{\max}(C)$. We may assume that $u_1=z_1>0$ and $|u_i|\le
z_i$ for all $i$. Then, using \eqref{EQ:DIAG1},

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\lambda_{\max}(C)u_{1}=\sum_{j}C_{1i}u_{i}\leq C_{11}u_{1}+\sum_{i>1}|C_{1i}|z%
_{i}=2C_{11}u_{1}<2cu_{1}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>max</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>C</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>u</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>j</mi></munder><mrow><msub><mi>C</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>u</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>C</mi><mn>11</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>u</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>></mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></munder><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mi>C</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>C</mi><mn>11</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>u</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mo><</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>u</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
which contradicts the choice of $c$.
\end{proof}

The assertion does not remain true without the weights. Consider two
isomorphic $D$-regular expanders $G_1$ and $G_2$, and connect them by
a path on the same number of nodes. The gap
$\lambda_2-\lambda_1=\lambda_2$ will be small; the gap
$\lambda_3-\lambda_2$ will be comparable with the eigenvalue gap of
$G_1$. The eigenvector of $\lambda_2$ will be close to a constant $a$
on $V(G_1)$, a $-a$ on $V(G_2)$, and small on the path. Its positive
support will be $V(G_1)$ together with half of the path; this is not
an expander in the unweighted sense.

It follows by a similar argument that

\begin{prop}\label{PROP:SUM}
If $y$ is an eigenvector belonging to $\lambda_k$, $a+b=k+1$, and
$\{V_1,\dots,V_a\}$ is a partition of $V^+$ and $\{U_1,\dots,U_b\}$
is a partition of $V^-$, then

\end{prop}

Indeed, notice that in the proof the matrix $C$ is positive
semidefinite, by a similar argument as for $C-B$. Hence its largest
eigenvalue is bounded above by its trace. Since $C-B$ is positive
semidefinite, it follows that $\mu_{a+b}\le {\text{\rm tr}}(C)=\sum_i C_{ii}$.
Substituting from \eqref{EQ:DIAG1}, the inequality follows.

\medskip

We remark in conclusion that it would be interesting to prove a
converse theorem, stating that if a graph cannot be partitioned into
more than $k+1$ weighted expanders, then there must be a large gap in
the eigenvalue sequence.

\end{proof}
